title: My Child Is Slower Than Classmates at Math – Should I Worry?
description: Understanding why some children work more slowly at math and when speed differences matter.
imageAlt: Child working carefully on math problems

content.intro: Your child seems capable but is consistently one of the last to finish math work. Other kids are done, and yours is still working. Is this a problem?

sections.text: Some of the best mathematicians are deliberate thinkers. Speed isn't the goal – understanding is.

sections.text: If basic facts aren't automatic, every calculation requires conscious thought. Practice until 7×8 is as instant as knowing your name.
Teach "good enough for now." It's better to finish with small errors than to leave questions blank.
Gradually introduce timed practice. Not to stress, but to build comfort with working at a reasonable pace.
If there's a documented processing speed issue, extended time is a common and reasonable accommodation.
Research shows that building automaticity with math facts dramatically improves overall math speed. It's not about rushing – it's about freeing up mental resources for actual problem-solving.

faq.question: Will my child always be slow at math?
faq.answer: Not necessarily. Speed often improves with fluency. Kids who build strong foundations and automatic recall usually speed up significantly.

faq.question: Should I time my child's homework?
faq.answer: Generally no for homework. But occasional timed practice sessions (5-10 minutes) can help build pace. Frame it as a game, not a pressure test.

faq.question: My child is accurate but slow. Is that okay?
faq.answer: Accuracy is more important than speed. But if slowness is impacting test performance or causing frustration, it's worth working on pace while maintaining accuracy.
